Official Website: http://squidsoft.net
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Humanity has just emerged from the lowest point in its collective history, and
the closest it has been to extinction since the advent of agriculture. By the
year 2304, the Coalition of humans and their alien allies the Jinu has spread
across the stars, and thought themselves powerful. But the Outsiders, an alien
empire occupying vast reaches of Rimward space, proved them wrong. First contact
between the two allies was severed, and suddenly humanity was alone. Then the
Outsiders attacked in force, and human planets and governments fell one by one.
                         It was the apocalypse.
But contrary to the beliefs of many, not all hope was lost. After five years,
a single starship, the Percival Lowell, returned from Rimward space, bringing
with it the means to nullify the Outsiders' greatest weapon. With this, and the
help of many other brave pilots, the occupying Outsiders were driven off human
               worlds and back to where they came from.
 Humanity is now trying to rebuild, and trying to regain what it has lost. The
Outsiders are finished with occupation, and now desire only to see humans
extinct.
New threats and new mysteries seem to appear every day. In the midst of it all,
civilian starships span the stars, maintaining an open threat against any new
       invasion and trying to make a few credits while they're at it.
You too have felt the lure of this; the desire for a unique freedom that most
citizens will never know, the drive to explore, the need to defend your species,
         and yes, greed for the vast wealth that is to be had.
                   It is time to take to the stars.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Welcome to the original and still the most innovative pulp science fiction
multiplayer roleplaying adventure!
Originally opened in its classic form on 19 December 1998! Reopened in its new
iteration on 28 February 2009!
All original work (including setting, non-player characters, design, source
code, all related background material, and all text) located in this game or on
the Squidsoft.net website is copyright (c) Squidsoft.net 1998-2015. Unauthorised
reproduction prohibited.
Warning: Speech in this game is largely uncensored, and sensitive individuals
may find some other players offensive. The staff is ultimately not responsible
for the words and actions of the players.
The last server reset was at Thu Aug 24 06:11:20 2017 UTC
We're on Twitter! @StarConquest for server status notifications and out-of-game
contact!
No new announcements to display.

If you do not yet have a Squidsoft.net account, type CREATE or visit the above
web address.

    * Welcome to Star Conquest! *
[Starship "William Dove"; Living Quarters One]
This is a small room designed to give crew members a place to sleep while on
long journeys, and it isn't large enough to do much else. A long counter is
bolted to the wall opposite the entryway, and two narrow bunks have been bolted
to the two remaining walls. A small keypad is next to the door, controlling a
simple lock. The status lights overhead are currently not receiving power.
Looking through the windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a dusky pink rattan cabinet, a small red ball containing a realistic
Bari horde noisemaker, a glossy pale purple ceramic felo chow bowl, a large oval
dark purple and light purple cloth rug, a white four poster rattan bed with a
heart-shaped headboard and filmy deep purple hangings with a soft periwinkle
cashmere blanket, a set of lavender silk sheets, a large periwinkle bed pillow,
a hand-made purple and amethyst flower quilt, and a large periwinkle bed pillow
on it, a small purple trash bin, a small oval turquoise rattan table with a
glass top, a pair of violet red leather boots decorated with neon red stars, a
pair of tan suede clogs, a pair of white leather clogs with a row of glittery
fireflies across the toes, Cheri-Pye the large light violet felo, and Prissy the
big violet long-haired felo here.
Lily Kaise, Phoenix Dissident is dozing on a white four poster rattan bed.
You can go out.
(You are lying on a white four poster rattan bed with a heart-shaped headboard
and filmy deep purple hangings with a soft periwinkle cashmere blanket, a set of
lavender silk sheets, a large periwinkle bed pillow, a hand-made purple and
amethyst flower quilt, and a large periwinkle bed pillow on it.)

[Starship "William Dove"; Observation Deck]
You see a large round light purple and dark purple cloth rug, an antique oak
table from Old Earth, a textured plasteel floor lamp with a cream shade (casting
a white-colored glow), a violet leather sectional sofa with Shine the sleeping
big white glowing felo on it, a glossy lilac ceramic felo chow bowl, a
wall-sized bubbling coral pink-lit aquarium containing light blue and white
aquatic life and coral rocks, a black plastic tray of spider chow, and a hairy
yellow eight-legged ArachnoPal named Higgins here.
You can go north, east, south, west, up, and down.
n
[Starship "William Dove"; Base Block]
You see a soft round ocean blue rug with a design of coral and turquoise
seashells, a blueberry rattan bench with a long white and coral pink flowered
cushion on it, a round white rattan dining table with a glass top, a blueberry
rattan bench with a long white and coral pink flowered cushion on it, a rattan
floor lamp with a coral lotus shade, a blueberry rattan pantry cabinet, a small
dusky pink trash bin, a glossy azure blue ceramic felo chow bowl, a black
plastic tray of spider chow, and Mischief the large black felo here.
You can go north, east, south, west, up, and down.

n

lamp with a light purple lotus shade (casting a white-colored glow), a wormhole
drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and
black cloth rug, a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and
sapphire star quilt on it, a round white rattan coffee table with a glass top, a
glossy silver ceramic felo chow bowl, a wall-sized bubbling neon purple-lit
aquarium containing yellow and red aquatic life and coral rocks, a black plastic
tray of spider chow, a compact white refrigerator, an insulated black cooler, a
robotic chef named Nellie, and Purr the humanoid service robot here.
You can go south and out.
You can't go that way.

[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Control Room]
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, a dark green leather
captain's chair, a small hot beverage dispenser, and a small hot coffee
dispenser here.

power
You grasp a large lever on the control board and push it slowly away from you.
Status lights blink on all around you as faint hums and beeps begin to emanate
from the various starship systems.
launch
You use the ship's radio to ask flight control for launch clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Deadly Strike, you are given undock
clearance under the AEU-EAOS non-aggression pact."
ftl chetumal
The ship is already moving.
ftl chetumal
What was once a feature of interstellar geography is now the name of an
alliance, and the heart of Fringe space can be found past this gateway. The tiny
station of Nuevo Laredo stands guard here.
The planet of Chetumal floats before you here, the richest planet among the
Fringe Worlds, although that isn't saying a lot.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to Chetumal in thirty seconds unless aborted or another navigation order
is entered."

ftl new
Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
Via general sector communication, AEU Battery-Powered Message Beacon transmits,
"There is nothing that will change the crushing reality that Outccord is a
failure! STOP Outccord right now!"
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to New Earth in thirty seconds unless aborted or another navigation
order is entered."
Via general sector communication, New Earth transmits, "Hello there, Deadly
Strike! Welcome to home space!"

[The Torus; Dock Alpha]
The pale gray walls, floor, and ceiling of this massive EAOS docking bay glow
with a pale white light. Though the bay remains open to space, it somehow also
retains its atmosphere. Outside, you can see the bright glint of a solitary
blue-white star. Signs indicate that the repair and rearm facility, the starship
supply store, and the main concourse are to the north.
The four-person star liner "Starlight Express" is landed here.
You see an automatic teller machine here.
You can go north and down.

l
[The Torus; East Concourse]
Though the curving walls and floor of this spacious corridor seem to be made of
bare gray metal, the walls, meeting seamlessly overhead in an arched ceiling,
glow softly with a pale white light, and the floor is such that it muffles even
the heaviest footfalls. On either side of the corridor is a row of tall windows
that provides on one side a glimpse of the inner curve of the opposite side of
the Torus and, on the other, the sight of the starry black space beyond the
station. A door leads to the Public Access Center.
You can go north and south.

ftl new
Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
Via general sector communication, AEU Battery-Powered Message Beacon transmits,
"There is nothing that will change the crushing reality that Outccord is a
failure! STOP Outccord right now!"
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to New Earth in thirty seconds unless aborted or another navigation
order is entered."
Via general sector communication, New Earth transmits, "Hello there, Kalina!
Welcome to home space!"

launch

ftl accord
A handful of lonely beacons watch over this area of space, their lights glowing
palely in the dark, surrounded by tendrils of drifting dust and debris.
A planet once existed here, until it was destroyed by the Outsiders. Now only
large chunks of the planet remain, still drifting slowly away from each other,
with clouds of debris filling the sector.
A circular space station dominates this sector, made of darkened metal
reinforced against attack. By the look of it, this is probably the most heavily
armored station in human space, excepting The Torus. This is the heart of the
Accord of Free Worlds.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to AFW Command (Dock One) in thirty seconds unless aborted or another
navigation order is entered."
move
Via general sector communication, Accord of Free Worlds Command transmits,
"Hello, Deadly Strike. Welcome to Accord space."
AutoStar detects 2 possible destinations.  Assembling destination list.  Please
wait.

ftl chetumal
tra 1 Hello AEU.
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Shule Elemmire, Phoenix Dissident transmits,
"Hello AEU."
What was once a feature of interstellar geography is now the name of an
alliance, and the heart of Fringe space can be found past this gateway. The tiny
station of Nuevo Laredo stands guard here.
The planet of Chetumal floats before you here, the richest planet among the
Fringe Worlds, although that isn't saying a lot.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to Chetumal in thirty seconds unless aborted or another navigation order
is entered."
Via general sector communication, Chetumal transmits, "Greetings, Deadly Strike!
Welcome to Chetumal Orbit!"

read paper
--
Ather jammoa,
You are certainly are assuming a lot. Eli asked me if I would be available at
20:00 on the 4th and I affirmed I would be. on the 4th at 20:00 and he did not
call to organize nor did he anything additional and I was available and ready.
Eli didn't notify us of his change of plan so that I could have at least let him
know I wouldn't be available but for about an hour on the 5th and I wasn't
available for but about a similar amount of time earlier this morning. I had
asked Shule and Constantine to keep an eye on the Range office for the temporary
stations we support. Shule, for personal reasons, isn't working much right now
as am I not able to work but on a limited basis particularly during the weekdays
and weekday evenings. I have no idea why Constantine didn't take care of his
assigned duty as a Trustee for SEAS without properly notifying me. Otherwise, I
would have made other arrangements to have someone else deploy the Beacon as it
went offline while i was away. So on the 5th and earlier this morning, I
couldn't be available. I will have some time around 22:30 this evening and will
sho if I can come into work sooner.
So, this has nothing to do with a willingness to support our cause. I know that
some would be just as angry if I didn't put up their Beacons and related but I
made a commitment to Libertarians maintain certain stations. Johann has not been
happy when i couldn't immediately deploy other stations at times so the pressure
was coming from more than one direction Ather and not that I really wanted to
spend the little time I had in the Rift. As I so would have rathr been there
with you and Eli. So did you ask all of the others why they weren't there?
Communications are key if you want to organize for a cause and especially this
one so Eli or yourself were certainly not effective with letting us all know
when to assemble and especially that the original time was postponed. Given my
own limitations, I for one was very sad and disappointed that we did nothing on
the 4th when this was originally planned. I have already been supportive through
being on hand for Eli's public broadcasts when I could. I have personally chased
off traders and supply ships and will continue to do so. I will also, as I said,
be on hand for as often as I can to protest or otherwise.
I was hopeful that the trip out to 777 wouldn't require as much time as it did
and I had to leave while the ship was in the Rift for most of the time so it was
flying on its own and obviously at risk but it was the best I could do.
I'm sorry that you have been so judgemental. It's obviously true that you and
Eli are indeed placing hostile pressure upon AEU pilots as well. Think about
your behavior and your own actions Ather. Also, ask questions before you make
assumptions of others. If you want others to be available, notice needs to be
given or other arrangements which were notified to us should follow through as
well. For shyer pilots, you are likely intimmidating them and this is not the
right time to behave in this manner as we need to work together but you are
already causing hostility amongst us when we need to come together and be
supportive of one another instead. So this is not a rant. It is merely an
expression of my disappointment in you Ather Jammoa.
As for the revocation of other organizations to SEAS Warehouse, it's
disappointing. However, I have such little time to be at work, that the
responsibilities often don't afford me much time for anything else while I am
able to be here and I am currently not seeing others stepping up to assist.
After their respective modules are depleted, I will revoke other organizations
access to SEAS Warehouse in kind. If they want assistance in the future and
restore SEAS, then we will return their status.
This letter will be distributed to all Organization Founders.
Lily Kaise

from the various starship systems.
launch
You use the ship's radio to ask flight control for launch clearance.

navigation order is entered."

Strike! Welcome to The Torus!"

A destination appears on the ship's navigation controls: The Torus (Dock Alpha).
The ship's computer automatically requests docking clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "We detect you to be an AEU ship,
Deadly Strike. The EAOS welcomes you under the non-aggression pact."
The computer sounds a notification indicating that the ship has been fully
charged.
power
You pull a large lever towards you.
The faint sounds and status lights of the starship's systems slowly fade away,
leaving you in a dim silence.
Your ship 'Deadly Strike' has been automatically moved into a garage.

[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, a dark green leather
captain's chair, a small hot beverage dispenser, and a small hot coffee
dispenser here.
You can go east, southeast, and out.
(You are sitting on a dark green leather captain's chair.)

dropped out of communications.

have not recently been active.
Final total: 28 pilots.

The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.

ftl chetumal
What was once a feature of interstellar geography is now the name of an
alliance, and the heart of Fringe space can be found past this gateway. The tiny
station of Nuevo Laredo stands guard here.
The planet of Chetumal floats before you here, the richest planet among the
Fringe Worlds, although that isn't saying a lot.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to Chetumal in thirty seconds unless aborted or another navigation order
is entered."

[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Control Room]
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, a dark green leather

power
You grasp a large lever on the control board and push it slowly away from you.
Status lights blink on all around you as faint hums and beeps begin to emanate
from the various starship systems.
launch
You use the ship's radio to ask flight control for launch clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Deadly Strike, you are given launch
clearance under the AEU-Fringe non-aggression pact."
The computer reports that the one-person fighter "Sweet Revenge" has landed on
the planet Chetumal.

The perfect ring of The Torus spins serenely nearby.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to The Torus (Dock Alpha) in thirty seconds unless aborted or another
navigation order is entered."

Strike! Welcome to The Torus!"

ships
There are no other ships in the sector.
Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
Via general sector communication, AEU Battery-Powered Message Beacon transmits,
"There is nothing that will change the crushing reality that Outccord is a
failure! STOP Outccord right now!"
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to New Earth in thirty seconds unless aborted or another navigation
order is entered."

l
[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, a dark green leather
captain's chair, a small hot beverage dispenser, and a small hot coffee
dispenser here.
You can go east, southeast, and out.
(You are sitting on a dark green leather captain's chair.)

power

Status lights blink on all around you as faint hums and beeps begin to emanate
from the various starship systems.
launch
You use the ship's radio to ask flight control for launch clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Deadly Strike, you are given undock
clearance under the AEU-EAOS non-aggression pact."

Lexie Amarras  (F)
Your communicator also reports that there is 1 pilot who was active but dropped
out of communications.

have not recently been active.
Final total: 18 pilots.
Want to know if anyone's relaxing in a public venue? Check WHERE!
Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to Providence Station in thirty seconds unless aborted or another
navigation order is entered."

l
[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, a dark green leather
captain's chair, a small hot beverage dispenser, and a small hot coffee
dispenser here.
You can go east, southeast, and out.

There appear to be about 5 pilots recently active.

dropped out of communications.

[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, a dark green leather
captain's chair, a small hot beverage dispenser, and a small hot coffee
dispenser here.
You can go east, southeast, and out.

 Star Conquest takes a lot of money to run. Please consider donating to offset
those costs.

 TIP: Did you know that you can use audible social commands on your
communicator? Try typing TRANSMIT LAUGH!

[Starship "William Dove"; Control Room]
You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor
lamp with a light purple lotus shade (casting a white-colored glow), a wormhole
drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and
black cloth rug, a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and
sapphire star quilt on it, a round white rattan coffee table with a glass top, a
glossy silver ceramic felo chow bowl, a wall-sized bubbling neon purple-lit
aquarium containing yellow and red aquatic life and coral rocks, a black plastic
tray of spider chow, a compact white refrigerator, an insulated black cooler, a
robotic chef named Nellie, and Purr the humanoid service robot here.
You can go south and out.

Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
Via general sector communication, AEU Battery-Powered Message Beacon transmits,
"There is nothing that will change the crushing reality that Outccord is a
failure! STOP Outccord right now!"
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to New Earth in thirty seconds unless aborted or another navigation
order is entered."

 You are wearing a long-sleeved dark green tee appliqued with small silver
stars, a stormy pair of trousers, and a pair of gray canvas sneakers. Underneath
this, you are wearing a pair of white cotton briefs and a pair of white socks.
You are also wearing a keychain, a backpack, a metallic gold touch einrophone in
a black leather phone holster, a solid silver ring engraved with dolphins, and a
gold wrist-mounted chronometer. You are concealing a metallic silver metachannel
FTL communicator, a flight control scanner, a large expandable telescoping
xenology container, a scorched metal thigh holster, a golden Feng Wo coin purse,
a camera bag, a black engineering tool case, a black flightbag with a red
shooting star on the side, and a leather briefcase. Your head, face, both eyes,
neck, both wrists, and both hands are left uncovered.
You are carrying nothing.

Flight Control: New Earth Orbit flight control, this is New Earth, an AEU
corvette is outbound.
A single star shines brightly in the dark here, the light strangely comforting.
The ship's sensors indicate that the star's spectrum is nearly identical to
Sol's.
Flight Control: This is Hyperion, we record an inbound AEU corvette.
Hyperion's famous Sea of Grass is immediately obvious upon gazing at the planet,
the rolling, meters-deep expanse of tall grasses obscuring the contours of the
surface.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to Hyperion in thirty seconds unless aborted or another navigation order
is entered."

turn scanner
You switch a flight control scanner off.
**
 Welcome back to Star Conquest!
**
 Star Conquest takes a lot of money to run. Please consider donating to offset
those costs.
 Type HELP DONATIONS for more information.
**
 TIP: As a pilot you want both license points and credits, but most activities
focus on one or the other.
**

[New Earth; Spaceport Landing Pad]
The busy landing pad of New Earth's capital city's spaceport sits over a large
bay at the tip of the southern continent. The pad itself is a huge square sheet
of white plasteel surrounded by gleaming new starship service structures. On the
southern side of the pad is a circular structure with wide transparisteel
windows affording a fabulous view of the ocean. A softly lit sign over the
transparisteel doorway reads, 'Pilot Lounge,' and a separate doorway is marked
'Liaison Office.' It looks like you can GO into either of those places. To the
west, a bridge spans the gap between the landing pad and the rest of the
spaceport.
You see an automatic teller machine, a small trash can, and a sanitation drone
here.
You can go north, south, west, and down.
A sanitation drone turns and slowly plods north.
A sanitation drone lumbers into the area.

the code H4, takes like 2 minutes."

intercepted by anyone with the tech to recieve them too, but it's more or less
instant, so no need to shorten messages."

[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, a dark green leather
captain's chair, a small hot beverage dispenser, and a small hot coffee
dispenser here.
You can go east, southeast, and out.
(You are sitting on a dark green leather captain's chair.)

[AEU | 10: Conquest Status] An AEU pilot corps liaison transmits, "Hello? Anyone
there?"
l
[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, a dark green leather
captain's chair, a small hot beverage dispenser, and a small hot coffee
dispenser here.
You can go east, southeast, and out.
power
You grasp a large lever on the control board and push it slowly away from you.
Status lights blink on all around you as faint hums and beeps begin to emanate
from the various starship systems.
launch
You use the ship's radio to ask flight control for launch clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Deadly Strike, you are given undock
clearance under the AEU-EAOS non-aggression pact."
ftl ardsley
The ship has arrived in the Campeche cluster, a solar system filled with a
wealth of colonizable planets.
ships
There are no other ships in the sector.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to Ardsley in thirty seconds unless aborted or another navigation order
is entered."
move

wait.

Destinations in this sector:
   Planets:
[1] Ardsley

Enter your destination:
Via general sector communication, Ardsley transmits, "Greetings, Deadly Strike!
Welcome to Ardsley Orbit!"
A destination appears on the ship's navigation controls: Ardsley.
The ship's computer automatically requests landing clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "We detect you to be an AEU ship,
Deadly Strike. The Fringe welcomes you under the non-aggression pact."
power
You pull a large lever towards you.
The faint sounds and status lights of the starship's systems slowly fade away,
leaving you in a dim silence.

[Ardsley; Barrington Street]
A big warehouse sits on the west side of the street here, a row of potted plants
along the front. A sign in front of it reads, 'Cranston Road Grocery.' A fast
food place called Barrington Burgers is located across the street, with a
playground attached to the back.

[Ardsley; Cranston Road]

l
[Ardsley; Cranston Road]
On the north side of this busy street is a row of old houses with large trees
lining the sidewalk. On the south side are new buildings, including a
construction company and several shops, among them The Glam Outlet, attracting
groups of young women dressed in shiny vinyl, and The Accessory Depot, which
displays all kinds of hair decorations in the show windows. A hot dog cart sits
outside on the sidewalk, attracting construction workers and shop employees.
You can go east and west.
e
[Ardsley; Cranston Road]
You can go west.
l
[Ardsley; Cranston Road]
Small shopping centers line this section of Cranston Road, the last new
development before the road continues east through industrial parks and housing
areas shining white and clean in the bright sun. To the west is Ardsley's main
shopping district, but here are two notable stores: Clompy's Clog Store, with a
display of leather clogs and casual clothing in the front windows, and
Rockabilly Threads, with a sign overhead reading, 'Grand Reopening!' and the
sound of old-fashioned swing music issuing from its front door.
You can go west.

large bay window made of thick plasteel that looks out on empty space, with
lovely views of ships taking off and landing. The walls are painted a neutral
off-white, and soft lighting from hidden sources fills the space.

[Starship "William Dove"; Living Quarters One]
This is a small room designed to give crew members a place to sleep while on
long journeys, and it isn't large enough to do much else. A long counter is
bolted to the wall opposite the entryway, and two narrow bunks have been bolted
to the two remaining walls. A small keypad is next to the door, controlling a
simple lock. The status lights overhead are currently not receiving power.
Looking through the windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a dusky pink rattan cabinet, a small red ball containing a realistic
Bari horde noisemaker, a glossy pale purple ceramic felo chow bowl, a large oval
dark purple and light purple cloth rug, a white four poster rattan bed with a
heart-shaped headboard and filmy deep purple hangings with a soft periwinkle
cashmere blanket, a set of lavender silk sheets, a large periwinkle bed pillow,
a hand-made purple and amethyst flower quilt, and a large periwinkle bed pillow
on it, a small purple trash bin, and a small oval turquoise rattan table with a
glass top here.

[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Patriot Constantine Stone transmits, "Did we
ever pin down how much the AEU pays the Accord each month?"
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Patriot Constantine Stone transmits, "Or get
some kind of ballpark."
[AEU | 10: Conquest Status] An AEU pilot corps liaison transmits, "No one is
doing anything? Someone must have an idea!"
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Eli Grey transmits, "No, The Accord couldn't
really give a number because a lot of what we send isn't really credits."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Eli Grey transmits, "It's like personnel, and
equipment."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Patriot Constantine Stone transmits, "That
makes sense."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Patriot Constantine Stone transmits, "I was
just trying to think about doing some napkin math. The only way I can think to
really put the squeeze on the government would be to make sure the Union saw no
financial gain from leaving the Accord."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Patriot Constantine Stone transmits, "But I'm
not even sure the strike and merchant blockage combined add up to a large enough
number."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Patriot Constantine Stone transmits,
"Certainly not to the, what was it, 500 billion Best quoted?"
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Eli Grey transmits, "Well one good thing, is
have you heard our conquest guy? This will be our least productive period yet I
think."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Patriot Constantine Stone transmits, "Yeah, it
will. What happened to Tara?"
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Eli Grey transmits, "I don't know."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Patriot Constantine Stone transmits, "Well
hopefully she comes back eventually."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Eli Grey transmits, "Maybe she took a break."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Eli Grey transmits, "Yeah, I hope so... I hate
to think that this stuff lost us people."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Patriot Constantine Stone transmits, "I'm
worried it definitely has. I haven't seen Aldis or Okinaj in quite a while."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Patriot Constantine Stone transmits, "Cadets
have high attrition in general, though. It might be hard to pin down an exact
cause."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Eli Grey transmits, "And yeah the figure given
in the press was five hundred billion a week which is yeah, a bit out there as
far as sums go."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Patriot Constantine Stone transmits, "Oh, a
week? Damn."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Patriot Constantine Stone transmits, "If
that's even close to being accurate..."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Patriot Constantine Stone transmits, "Well, no
amount of merchant blocking or striking will help."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Patriot Constantine Stone transmits, "I got
bored today and pulled 70 artifacts out of the bubble."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Patriot Constantine Stone transmits, "That's
probably about a billion credits they won't be able to tax until the strike
ends, but still."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Patriot Constantine Stone transmits, "That's
nowhere near 500 billion a week."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Eli Grey transmits, "According to Shea, it's
misleading at best, because of it not being credits."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Patriot Constantine Stone transmits, "Yeah."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Eli Grey transmits, "The idea of putting a
credit value on something like personnel seems maybe just a bit sleazy."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Patriot Constantine Stone transmits, "Yeah,
but potentially necessary from an accounting perspective."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Eli Grey transmits, "Very true."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Patriot Constantine Stone transmits, "These
are the kinds of things that factor into their calculus in the negotiations, I'm
sure."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Patriot Constantine Stone transmits, "I've
still heard nothing about whether the govnerment has asked the office to try to
end the strike."
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Patriot Constantine Stone transmits, "Though
it has only been two days."

there?"

[General Communication] Tanny Hill transmits, "Sup."
[General Communication] Ted Warburton transmits, "I swear that's the only word I
ever hear you say these days."
[General Communication] Tanny Hill transmits, "It's the song of my people."
[General Communication] Ted Warburton transmits, "The only one?"
[General Communication] Tanny Hill transmits, "We're not super diverse."
[General Communication] Ted Warburton transmits, "My work is done."
[General Communication] Tanny Hill transmits, "I thought y'all were going back
to the thing out there. Is that over now?"
[General Communication] Ted Warburton transmits, "I haven't been over at all,
but I didn't see any ops in the last 24 hours."
[General Communication] Egil Aurstad transmits, "Hello."
[General Communication] Ted Warburton transmits, "Hi."
[General Communication] Tanny Hill transmits, "Oh, I thought you were one of the
people who got blown up with Damien."
[General Communication] Ted Warburton transmits, "Nope, not me, last time I
found I wasn't awake enough when ops happened, so this time I didn't go, always
too quiet for them at this time of day."
[General Communication] Egil Aurstad transmits, "Who got blown up where?"
[General Communication] Ted Warburton transmits, "Nasty sounding attack on one
of the salvage ops on the trip."
[General Communication] Damien Goss transmits, "Nine Outsiders, lots of warpers,
and interdicted."
[General Communication] Ted Warburton transmits, "And I heard you were flying,
and I know how good an evader you can be, and that you would have tried to get
the interdictors if you could."
[General Communication] Egil Aurstad transmits, "I don't know what warpers and
interdiction means, but it sounds really bad."
[General Communication] Tanny Hill transmits, "Interdiction means no escape."
[General Communication] Damien Goss transmits, "Yeah, except we didn't know
exactly who the interdictors were. The rapid wouldn't leave off Johann's
transport and so we spent the first part chasing that fool around the sector."
[General Communication] Ted Warburton transmits, "Yeah, rapids have to go first,
they are a royal pain."
[General Communication] Ted Warburton transmits, "It was you and Johann, two of
our best for that kind of situation."
[General Communication] Damien Goss transmits, "We think however that the one
interdicting was the martial fighter. At least we were allowed to leave after it
was destroyed, but all the warpers were gone by then too, so we are unsure about
that point."
[General Communication] Ted Warburton transmits, "We seem to be seeing more and
more warpers."
[General Communication] Tanny Hill transmits, "Egil, to explain here,
interdictors prevent ships from leaving the sector by any means, and assault
warping is a nasty upgrade some Outsider ships have where they teleport right
next to you guns blazing."
[General Communication] Egil Aurstad transmits, "That's cheating."
[General Communication] Tanny Hill transmits, "Sure is."
[General Communication] Ted Warburton transmits, "Wait till you meet the IFS,
with their long range lasers."
[General Communication] Egil Aurstad transmits, "Real fighters get up close and
personal, no less than a couple of kilometers, tops."
[General Communication] Egil Aurstad transmits, "More, even."
[General Communication] Ted Warburton transmits, "I wouldn't say things like
that if I were you, everybody has different ways of fighting."
[General Communication] Egil Aurstad transmits, "I was just joking about
distance. A fist fight equivalent in space would still have the ships really,
really far apart."
[General Communication] Tanny Hill transmits, "Alright, let's see, what to
do..."
[General Communication] Tanny Hill transmits, "Tesla?"
[General Communication] Ted Warburton transmits, "I can't do anything right
now."
[General Communication] Tanny Hill transmits, "Lame."
[General Communication] Egil Aurstad transmits, "Tesla?"
[General Communication] Ted Warburton transmits, "You need a battlesuit plus 20
million to register."
[General Communication] Egil Aurstad transmits, "I can afford that."
[General Communication] Ted Warburton transmits, "Do you have a battlesuit yet?"
[General Communication] Egil Aurstad transmits, "I have a tier 1 AEU suit."
[General Communication] Ted Warburton transmits, "Cool."
[General Communication] Tanny Hill transmits, "Teslaworld, to explain further,
is a planet ravaged by crazy radiation and electrical storms. It also happens to
have valuable resources underground and a fuckton of tunnels."
[General Communication] Egil Aurstad transmits, "Ohh."
A Tardick lizard named Asteria trundles slowly into the area.
[General Communication] Tanny Hill transmits, "It's pretty neat."
[General Communication] Ted Warburton transmits, "I'm half dozing doing a mine
right now, so if I go quiet, you know why."
[General Communication] Egil Aurstad transmits, "How's the pay?"
[General Communication] Tanny Hill transmits, "We use our battlesuits to mine
those resources and do battle with illegal poachers who want the stuff for
themselves. Pay is decent and versatile, you get to choose whether you want more
points or more credits."
[General Communication] Tanny Hill transmits, "And like many activities, the
more you do it, the more lucrative it gets."
A Tardick lizard named Asteria flicks its tail.
[General Communication] Egil Aurstad transmits, "Sounds convenient!"
[General Communication] Tanny Hill transmits, "Even better, you can do it alone
or with others."
[General Communication] Egil Aurstad transmits, "I get the feeling Tesla is one
of your favorite things."
[General Communication] Tanny Hill transmits, "It's pretty great."
[General Communication] Tanny Hill transmits, "I'm also bored and tired and thus
prone to rambling."
[General Communication] Egil Aurstad laughs.
[General Communication] Egil Aurstad transmits, "Informative rambling! Thanks."
[AEU | 10: Conquest Status] An AEU pilot corps liaison transmits, "Come on,
we're not even on the board! Let's do some piloting!"

all your SVP missions yet?"

those let me know."

indifferent to its surroundings.

curled up in bed."
A Tardick lizard named Asteria trundles slowly out.

[Starship "William Dove"; Living Quarters One]
This is a small room designed to give crew members a place to sleep while on
long journeys, and it isn't large enough to do much else. A long counter is
bolted to the wall opposite the entryway, and two narrow bunks have been bolted
to the two remaining walls. A small keypad is next to the door, controlling a
simple lock. The status lights overhead are currently not receiving power.
Looking through the windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a dusky pink rattan cabinet, a small red ball containing a realistic
Bari horde noisemaker, a glossy pale purple ceramic felo chow bowl, a large oval
dark purple and light purple cloth rug, a white four poster rattan bed with a
heart-shaped headboard and filmy deep purple hangings with a soft periwinkle
cashmere blanket, a set of lavender silk sheets, a large periwinkle bed pillow,
a hand-made purple and amethyst flower quilt, and a large periwinkle bed pillow
on it, a small purple trash bin, and a small oval turquoise rattan table with a
glass top here.
You can go out.
(You are lying on a white four poster rattan bed with a heart-shaped headboard
and filmy deep purple hangings with a soft periwinkle cashmere blanket, a set of
lavender silk sheets, a large periwinkle bed pillow, a hand-made purple and
amethyst flower quilt, and a large periwinkle bed pillow on it.)

You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor
lamp with a light purple lotus shade (casting a white-colored glow), a wormhole
drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and
black cloth rug, a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and
sapphire star quilt on it, a round white rattan coffee table with a glass top, a
glossy silver ceramic felo chow bowl, a wall-sized bubbling neon purple-lit
aquarium containing yellow and red aquatic life and coral rocks, a black plastic
tray of spider chow, a compact white refrigerator, an insulated black cooler, a
robotic chef named Nellie, and Purr the humanoid service robot here.

You can go south and out.
l
[Starship "William Dove"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor
lamp with a light purple lotus shade (casting a white-colored glow), a wormhole
drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and
black cloth rug, a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and
sapphire star quilt on it, a round white rattan coffee table with a glass top, a
glossy silver ceramic felo chow bowl, a wall-sized bubbling neon purple-lit
aquarium containing yellow and red aquatic life and coral rocks, a black plastic
tray of spider chow, a compact white refrigerator, an insulated black cooler, a
robotic chef named Nellie, and Purr the humanoid service robot here.
Lily Kaise, Phoenix Dissident is dozing on a rare black EAOSian contoured couch.
You can go south and out.

launch

clearance under the AEU-EAOS non-aggression pact."
ftl chetumal
What was once a feature of interstellar geography is now the name of an
alliance, and the heart of Fringe space can be found past this gateway. The tiny
station of Nuevo Laredo stands guard here.
The planet of Chetumal floats before you here, the richest planet among the
Fringe Worlds, although that isn't saying a lot.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to Chetumal in thirty seconds unless aborted or another navigation order
is entered."
move
AutoStar detects 2 possible destinations.  Assembling destination list.  Please
wait.
--
AutoStar (general-purpose starship autopilot) Version 9.1
--
Destinations in this sector:
   Planets:
[1] Chetumal                                                
   Space Markets:
[2] Space Market                                            
--
Enter your destination:
1
A destination appears on the ship's navigation controls: Chetumal.
Via general sector communication, Chetumal transmits, "Greetings, Deadly Strike!
Welcome to Chetumal Orbit!"
The ship's computer automatically requests landing clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "We detect you to be an AEU ship,
Deadly Strike. The Fringe welcomes you to the city of Chetumal City under the
non-aggression pact."
The computer sounds a notification indicating that the ship has been fully
charged.
power
You pull a large lever towards you.
The faint sounds and status lights of the starship's systems slowly fade away,
leaving you in a dim silence.

The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to The Torus (Dock Alpha) in thirty seconds unless aborted or another
navigation order is entered."
move

wait.

eta
The ship's current engine speed is 6857 km/s.
At that speed, the ship will arrive at its current autopilot destination in
about 5.2 seconds.
The ship's computer automatically requests docking clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "We detect you to be an AEU ship,
Deadly Strike. The EAOS welcomes you under the non-aggression pact."
power
You pull a large lever towards you.
The faint sounds and status lights of the starship's systems slowly fade away,
leaving you in a dim silence.
The computer sounds a notification indicating that the ship has been fully
charged.
Your ship 'Deadly Strike' has been automatically moved into a garage.

[Starship "William Dove"; Control Room]
You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor
lamp with a light purple lotus shade (casting a white-colored glow), a wormhole
drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and
black cloth rug, a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and
sapphire star quilt on it, a round white rattan coffee table with a glass top, a
glossy silver ceramic felo chow bowl, a wall-sized bubbling neon purple-lit
aquarium containing yellow and red aquatic life and coral rocks, a black plastic
tray of spider chow, a compact white refrigerator, an insulated black cooler, a
robotic chef named Nellie, and Purr the humanoid service robot here.
Lily Kaise, Phoenix Dissident is dozing on a rare black EAOSian contoured couch.
You can go south and out.
l lily
Lily Kaise, Phoenix Dissident
She appears to be 28 years old. She is about five feet and two inches tall and
has fair skin. Her body is thin with attractively curved hips and shapely
calves. She has slender shoulders and slightly larger than average breasts. Her
face is oval and pretty, with a delicate nose and understated chin. Her lips are
lovely and blush pink and occasionally part to reveal a set of pretty teeth.
Beneath a set of arched eyebrows, her eyes are blue-green and almond-shaped. Her
waist-length, straight hair is pale honey blonde and swept up into a thick fall
of loose curls down her back. She has oval pink fingernails.
A small enameled cerulean blue dragonfly pierces her left earlobe and a small
enameled cerulean blue dragonfly pierces her right earlobe.
 She is wearing a long-sleeved dark purple tee with a large neon purple dragon
appliqued on the front, a pair of blue stonewashed denim jeans with a small dark
red 'XX' embroidered on the left front pocket, and a pair of mystic purple suede
clogs. She is also wearing an orange and white blessed prayer bracelet around
her wrist, a slender bracelet of tiny tinkling silver bells around her wrist, a
neon purple wrist-mounted chronometer, a solid silver ring engraved with
dragonflies, a delicate ring of silver wire and small purple amethyst crystals,
a metallic gold touch einrophone in a metallic purple reinforced plastic phone
holster, an elegant white gold ring inset with a perfect solitaire diamond, a
light purple flightbag with a pastel kitten on the side, and a soft fuchsia
Tardick lizard snuggly labeled 'Asteria'. Her head, face, both eyes, neck, both
wrists, and both hands are left uncovered.
She is carrying nothing.
pet shine

[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, a small hot beverage
dispenser, a small hot coffee dispenser, and an overstuffed dark green chair
here.
Lily Kaise, Phoenix Dissident is dozing on an overstuffed dark green chair.
You can go east, southeast, and out.
(You are sitting on an overstuffed dark green chair.)

those costs.
 Type HELP DONATIONS for more information.

 TIP: Enjoy occasional unprovoked interactions with NPCs? Opt into 'Outside
Interference' events!

[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, a small hot beverage
dispenser, a small hot coffee dispenser, and an overstuffed dark green chair
here.
Lily Kaise, Phoenix Dissident is dozing on an overstuffed dark green chair.
You can go east, southeast, and out.

A handful of lonely beacons watch over this area of space, their lights glowing
palely in the dark, surrounded by tendrils of drifting dust and debris.
A planet once existed here, until it was destroyed by the Outsiders. Now only
large chunks of the planet remain, still drifting slowly away from each other,
with clouds of debris filling the sector.
A circular space station dominates this sector, made of darkened metal
reinforced against attack. By the look of it, this is probably the most heavily
armored station in human space, excepting The Torus. This is the heart of the
Accord of Free Worlds.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to AFW Command (Dock One) in thirty seconds unless aborted or another
navigation order is entered."

l
[Starship "William Dove"; Living Quarters One]
This is a small room designed to give crew members a place to sleep while on
long journeys, and it isn't large enough to do much else. A long counter is
bolted to the wall opposite the entryway, and two narrow bunks have been bolted
to the two remaining walls. A small keypad is next to the door, controlling a
simple lock. The status lights overhead are currently not receiving power.
Looking through the windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a dusky pink rattan cabinet, a small red ball containing a realistic
Bari horde noisemaker, a glossy pale purple ceramic felo chow bowl, a large oval
dark purple and light purple cloth rug, a white four poster rattan bed with a
heart-shaped headboard and filmy deep purple hangings with a soft periwinkle
cashmere blanket, a set of lavender silk sheets, a large periwinkle bed pillow,
a hand-made purple and amethyst flower quilt, and a large periwinkle bed pillow
on it, a small purple trash bin, and a small oval turquoise rattan table with a
glass top here.
You can go out.
(You are lying on a white four poster rattan bed with a heart-shaped headboard
and filmy deep purple hangings with a soft periwinkle cashmere blanket, a set of
lavender silk sheets, a large periwinkle bed pillow, a hand-made purple and
amethyst flower quilt, and a large periwinkle bed pillow on it.)

l lily
Lily Kaise, Phoenix Dissident
She appears to be 28 years old. She is about five feet and two inches tall and
has fair skin. Her body is thin with attractively curved hips and shapely
calves. She has slender shoulders and slightly larger than average breasts. Her
face is oval and pretty, with a delicate nose and understated chin. Her lips are
lovely and blush pink and occasionally part to reveal a set of pretty teeth.
Beneath a set of arched eyebrows, her eyes are blue-green and almond-shaped. Her
waist-length, straight hair is pale honey blonde and swept up into a thick fall
of loose curls down her back. She has oval pink fingernails.
A small enameled cerulean blue dragonfly pierces her left earlobe and a small
enameled cerulean blue dragonfly pierces her right earlobe.
 She is wearing a long-sleeved dark blue tee appliqued with small neon purple
flowers, a pair of tight white denim jeans with a small dark-red 'XX'
embroidered on the back left pocket, and a pair of white leather clogs with a
row of glittery fireflies across the toes. She is also wearing an orange and
white blessed prayer bracelet around her wrist, a slender bracelet of tiny
tinkling silver bells around her wrist, a neon purple wrist-mounted chronometer,
a solid silver ring engraved with dragonflies, a delicate ring of silver wire
and small purple amethyst crystals, a metallic gold touch einrophone in a
metallic purple reinforced plastic phone holster, an elegant white gold ring
inset with a perfect solitaire diamond, a light purple flightbag with a pastel
kitten on the side, a soft fuchsia Tardick lizard snuggly labeled 'Asteria', and
a Tardick lizard named Asteria perched on her shoulder. Her head, face, both
eyes, neck, both wrists, and both hands are left uncovered.
She is carrying Prissy the sleeping big violet long-haired felo in her right
hand.

l
[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, a small hot beverage
dispenser, a small hot coffee dispenser, and an overstuffed dark green chair
here.
You can go east, southeast, and out.
(You are sitting on an overstuffed dark green chair.)

[New Earth; Spaceport Landing Pad]
The busy landing pad of New Earth's capital city's spaceport sits over a large
bay at the tip of the southern continent. The pad itself is a huge square sheet
of white plasteel surrounded by gleaming new starship service structures. On the
southern side of the pad is a circular structure with wide transparisteel
windows affording a fabulous view of the ocean. A softly lit sign over the
transparisteel doorway reads, 'Pilot Lounge,' and a separate doorway is marked
'Liaison Office.' It looks like you can GO into either of those places. To the
west, a bridge spans the gap between the landing pad and the rest of the
spaceport.
The advanced scout "Celtic Rose" and the two-person flare "Deadly Strike" are
landed here.
You see an automatic teller machine, a small trash can, and a sanitation drone
here.
You can go north, south, west, and down.
launch
You use the ship's radio to ask flight control for launch clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Deadly Strike, you have clearance to
launch. Good luck and come back to us safely."

bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.

l
[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, a small hot beverage
dispenser, a small hot coffee dispenser, and an overstuffed dark green chair
here.
Lily Kaise, Phoenix Dissident is dozing on an overstuffed dark green chair.
You can go east, southeast, and out.
(You are sitting on an overstuffed dark green chair.)

[New Earth; Spaceport Landing Pad]
The busy landing pad of New Earth's capital city's spaceport sits over a large
bay at the tip of the southern continent. The pad itself is a huge square sheet
of white plasteel surrounded by gleaming new starship service structures. On the
southern side of the pad is a circular structure with wide transparisteel
windows affording a fabulous view of the ocean. A softly lit sign over the
transparisteel doorway reads, 'Pilot Lounge,' and a separate doorway is marked
'Liaison Office.' It looks like you can GO into either of those places. To the
west, a bridge spans the gap between the landing pad and the rest of the
spaceport.
The two-person flare "Deadly Strike" is landed here.
You see an automatic teller machine and a small trash can here.
You can go north, south, west, and down.

your left hand.

alliance, and the heart of Fringe space can be found past this gateway. The tiny
station of Nuevo Laredo stands guard here.

[Starship "William Dove"; "Hope"]]
Unlike the control room, a starship's weapon room has only one tiny viewport.
The focus of the room is a slightly miniaturized starmap, augmented with
additional spatial relationship information and various status displays. A
streamlined control board sits before the starmap, with prominent indicators for
lock status and weapon readiness. Control boards for the ship's weaponry are off
to either side, to be pulled into place at a moment's notice. The status lights
overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the windows, you see
that the ship is in a garage.
You see a silky electric blue cushion decorated with embroidered pale blue
flowers, a glossy silver ceramic felo chow bowl, Desiree the little black and
white spotted CatBot, a large bubbling azure blue-lit aquarium containing violet
and ocher aquatic life and round rocks, Shule Elemmire's workbench, and Kiska
the humanoid service robot here.

[The Torus; Dock Alpha]
The pale gray walls, floor, and ceiling of this massive EAOS docking bay glow
with a pale white light. Though the bay remains open to space, it somehow also
retains its atmosphere. Outside, you can see the bright glint of a solitary
blue-white star. Signs indicate that the repair and rearm facility, the starship
supply store, and the main concourse are to the north.

l
[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, a small hot beverage
dispenser, a small hot coffee dispenser, and an overstuffed dark green chair
here.
Lily Kaise, Phoenix Dissident is dozing on an overstuffed dark green chair.
You can go east, southeast, and out.
(You are sitting on an overstuffed dark green chair.)

[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Airlock]

enter
[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Control Room]
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, a small hot beverage
dispenser, a small hot coffee dispenser, and an overstuffed dark green chair
here.
Lily Kaise, Phoenix Dissident is dozing on an overstuffed dark green chair.
You can go east, southeast, and out.
power
You grasp a large lever on the control board and push it slowly away from you.
Status lights blink on all around you as faint hums and beeps begin to emanate
from the various starship systems.
laucnh
I don't understand that.
launch
You use the ship's radio to ask flight control for launch clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Deadly Strike, you are given undock
clearance under the AEU-EAOS non-aggression pact."
ftl new
[Tactical Communication] Ali Candan transmits, "Camp?"
Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
Via general sector communication, AEU Battery-Powered Message Beacon transmits,
"There is nothing that will change the crushing reality that Outccord is a
failure! STOP Outccord right now!"
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.
The computer announces, "Autolander beacon detected. The ship will automatically
proceed to New Earth in thirty seconds unless aborted or another navigation
order is entered."
move
AutoStar detects 5 possible destinations.  Assembling destination list.  Please
wait.

[2] Space Station Alpha

Enter your destination:
Via general sector communication, AEU Battery-Powered Message Beacon transmits,
"Supporting Outccord equals supporting the extinction of all of humanity. Make
your choice carefully!"
Via general sector communication, New Earth transmits, "Hello there, Deadly
Strike! Welcome to home space!"
A destination appears on the ship's navigation controls: New Earth.
The ship's computer automatically requests landing clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Hello, Deadly Strike. We read your AEU
transponder. You are cleared to land at the city of New Phoenix."
power
You pull a large lever towards you.
The faint sounds and status lights of the starship's systems slowly fade away,
leaving you in a dim silence.
The computer sounds a notification indicating that the ship has been fully
charged.
Your ship 'Deadly Strike' has been automatically moved into a garage.
peer out
Not much to see out there.

[New Earth; Piper Wincott Memorial Garage]
You see a large number of stored starships here.

l
[New Earth; Piper Wincott Memorial Garage]
Even though this starship garage smells like machine oil and heavy lubricants,
it is spacious and well-lit. Massive hydraulic systems raise and lower starships
to and from the landing pad above, and technicians and mechanics in silvery gray
coveralls ensure that everything keeps running smoothly. A well-lit stairway
which leads to the pilot's lounge is here. The distinct smell of death is
emanating from the two-person medium transport "Silver Starlight".
You see a large number of stored starships here.
You see a sanitation drone here.
You can go up.
u
[New Earth; Spaceport Landing Pad]
You see an automatic teller machine, a small trash can, and a sanitation drone
here.
You can go north, south, west, and down.
w
[New Earth; Spaceport Bridge]
You see a trash can and a long white plasteel bench here.
You can go east and west.
smell me
You sniff at yourself. You smell the fresh fragrance of a sun-warmed grassy
meadow.
w
[New Earth; Spaceport East]
You can go northeast, east, southeast, south, southwest, and west.
i
 You are wearing a soft Bahama blue cotton polo, a pair of slim navy blue linen
trousers, and a pair of washed light khaki canvas sneakers. Underneath this, you
are wearing a pair of white cotton briefs and a pair of white socks. You are
also wearing a keychain, a backpack, a metallic gold touch einrophone in a black
leather phone holster, a solid silver ring engraved with dolphins, and a gold
wrist-mounted chronometer. You are concealing a metallic silver metachannel FTL
communicator, a flight control scanner, a large expandable telescoping xenology
container, a scorched metal thigh holster, a golden Feng Wo coin purse, a camera
bag, a black engineering tool case, a black flightbag with a red shooting star
on the side, and a leather briefcase. Your head, face, both eyes, neck, both
elbows, both forearms, both wrists, and both hands are left uncovered.
You are carrying nothing.

[Starship "Deadly Strike"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, a small hot beverage
dispenser, a small hot coffee dispenser, and an overstuffed dark green chair
here.
Lily Kaise, Phoenix Dissident is dozing on an overstuffed dark green chair.
You can go east, southeast, and out.
(You are sitting on an overstuffed dark green chair.)
e
You scramble to your feet.

You see an improved temporary wormhole drive and an overstuffed dark green chair
here.
You can go west.

[New Earth; Piper Wincott Memorial Garage]
Even though this starship garage smells like machine oil and heavy lubricants,
it is spacious and well-lit. Massive hydraulic systems raise and lower starships
to and from the landing pad above, and technicians and mechanics in silvery gray
coveralls ensure that everything keeps running smoothly. A well-lit stairway
which leads to the pilot's lounge is here. The distinct smell of death is
emanating from the two-person medium transport "Silver Starlight".
You can go up.

--
You're assuming quite a bit here Lily.
For the first thing, like I said, Ather asked the orgs to remove Seas. You can
go ahead and ask anyone you like.
We are an org, and so we did what he asked.
It was me who physically removed the parts from your warehouse, sure, but that
again, was going along with what Ather wanted.
Just because I physically removed the parts, doesn't mean I should get the blame
for this situation at all.
And do you honestly think after all the time and effort I've put into 777 that
I'd be putting it aside? Well you didn't ask, you just assumed, so let me
clarify.
I definitely plan to continue building, but I have managed to convince cats to
join this.
So if your concern is newer pilots, well it's going to be even better for them
now, because of the better speed getting there etcetera.
But you didn't think to ask, you just abused me and lost your patience.
Sometimes asking questions gets you much further.
Like I said, I have no drama at all with you as a person, or with the members of
your org.
So you can say I'm stabbing you in the back all you want, but that's not the
case.
I know that you clearly need to get your facts straight, and again, I'd be happy
to help you do that.
But name-calling doesn't get you anywhere.
I haven't called you one nasty thing after all you've said, and I could have.
But unlike what you seem to think, I don't have a problem with you.
But hell, if you thinking that makes your life easier, go ahead.
The fact is I'm trying to better 777.
But of course you didn't give me the chance to explain that.
--
